en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alice_Verlet "Alice Verlet (1873 – 1934) was a Belgian-born operatic coloratura soprano active primarily in France. She sang principal roles at the operas in Lyon, Nice, and Monte Carlo; at His Majesty's Theater in London; at La Monnaie in Brussels; and at the Paris Opéra and Opéra-Comique. In the United States, although not entirely absent from the operatic stage, she was known primarily as a concert singer and was a featured singer on Edison records." According to the Wikipedia article, she toured the U.S. in March 1922.

USS Saratoga (CV-3) was initially laid down as a battlecruiser (USS Saratoga (CC-3)), While under construction she'd be converted into an aircraft carrier (along with the namesake of the class, USS Lexington (CV-2)), due to the limitations of the 1922 Washington Naval Conference. She was launched at New York Shipbuilding, Camden, NJ, on April 7, 1925. She'd go one to have one of the most distinguished battle records of any American warship. Eventually, she would be used as a test target and sunk by the detonation of an atomic device at Bikini Atoll on July 25, 1946, during Operation Crossroads. See: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Saratoga_(CV-3) en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Crossroads

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Proteus_Steinmetz "Charles Proteus Steinmetz (born Karl August Rudolph Steinmetz, April 9, 1865 – October 26, 1923) was a German-born American mathematician and electrical engineer and professor at Union College. He fostered the development of alternating current that made possible the expansion of the electric power industry in the United States, formulating mathematical theories for engineers. He made ground-breaking discoveries in the understanding of hysteresis that enabled engineers to design better electromagnetic apparatus equipment including especially electric motors for use in industry."
See

Steinmetz was much in the news in March 1922. For example, an article in The Evening Star. In the NY Times of March 19, 1922:

"500 HEALTH HIKERS GET HYLAN SEND-OFF

Mayor, Dr. Copeland and Other Officials Watch Start From City Hall. MANY FALL OUT ON WAY Others Join Marchers, With Central Park as Goal—Woman Heads for Albany.

There were probably a thousand persons crowded in front of the City Hall yesterday afternoon when the first of a series of health hikes under the leadership of Captain Godfrey Rodrigues, a physical instructor, of Holland, started.

....

At least 500 followed the instructor across the park and into Lafayette Street."
According to The New York herald. [volume], March 19, 1922, Page 3, col. 2, only 52 people took part in the hike (instead of 300'000) chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045774/1922-03-19/ed-...

Freitag-Loringhoven, Elsa von,--1874-1927 The University of Maryland has a special collection about Elsa von Freytag-Loringhoven. She was an avant-garde artist and poet associated with Djuna Barnes and the Dada movement. Her papers consist of correspondence, poetry, and biographical and autobiographical notes and manuscripts documenting her life and literary career. Among the significant correspondents are Djuna Barnes, Peggy Guggenheim, and Berenice Abbott. See archives.lib.umd.edu/repositories/2/resources/22

There are two identical buildings on each side of the Taj Mahal, a mosque (Kau Ban Mosque) on the western and and the Mehmaan Khana (Guest House) on the eastern side. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alice_Paul "Alice Stokes Paul (January 11, 1885 – July 9, 1977) was an American socialist, suffragist, feminist, and women's rights activist, and one of the main leaders and strategists of the campaign for the Nineteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, which prohibits sex discrimination in the right to vote. Paul initiated, and along with Lucy Burns and others, strategized events such as the Woman Suffrage Procession and the Silent Sentinels, which were part of the successful campaign that resulted in the amendment's passage in 1920."

In 1922, Paul was vice-president of the National Woman's Party (NWP) (s. caption of photo in Woman's enterprise. [volume], March 10, 1922, Monthly, Page 5 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn89059303/1922-03-10/ed-...). In March 1922, she was in the newspapers in connecton with the purchase of a building for the headquarters of the NPD, s. article and photo in The Washington times. [volume], March 19, 1922, SUNDAY MORNING, Image 17 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1922-03-19/ed-... The new headquarters: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/49248308408/

This photograph shows NOT the Sewall-Belmont house (since 1929 the headquarters of the National Woman's Party (NWP), s. www.nps.gov/nr/travel/wash/dc82.htm). It's the "Old Brick Capitol" or "Back Capitol", where the Congress met from 1815 until 1819, while the real Capitol was rebuilt, after having been burned by the British. The NWP bought this house in 1921, s. caption of photo in The New York herald. [volume], August 14, 1921, SECTION FIVE ROTOGRAPHIC SECTION, Image 58 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045774/1921-08-14/ed-... and article in The New York herald. [volume], May 23, 1921, SECTION SEVEN, Page 2, Image 78 "Why the Woman's Watch Tower" chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045774/1921-05-23/ed-.... S. also www.culturaltourismdc.org/portal/united-states-supreme-co... The building was torn down to make way for the new U. S. Supreme Court building, s. caption of photo in the New Britain herald. [volume], June 11, 1930, Second Section, Image 14 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014519/1930-06-11/ed-....

From The midland journal., August 01, 1930, Image 7, "The Passing of a Landmark": "In 1921 Mrs. O. H. P. Belmont bought the building and presented it to the National Woman’s party for its national headquarters. It became a gathering place for the feminists, not only of America but 'of the whole world, and there was carried on the work for tlie freedom and equality of women. Finally the government, in seeking a site for the new Supreme court building, selected this one, instituted condemnation proceedings two years ago, and this year the work of razing it began." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn89060136/1930-08-01/ed-... (Mrs. O. H. P. Belmont resp. Alva Belmont was president of the National Woman's Party, s. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alva_Belmont) A. Belmont: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/8079896358/
Thanks for helpfully distinguishing which headquarters this is. We'll add some information to the description.

Grace Hoffman (????-????), American coloratura soprano A photo of her is in www.holdridgerecords.com/auction_pdfs/17.2_Cylinders_Ed_D..., p. 24 with the caption: "A 1915 Musical Monitor article cites Miss Hoffman, an American coloratura soprano, as “still in her early 20s” and having toured extensively as a soloist with Sousa’s Band and as a member of the Aborn Opera Company and then the U.S. touring Milan Opera Company. Her roles included, among others, Gilda, Oscar in Un Ballo in Maschera, and Micaëla in Carmen. She was a graduate of Smith College where in addition to music she studied psychology. Her interesting process of memorizing her roles was done early in the morning, around 6:00 or 7:00 a.m., “lying flat on my back in bed or on the floor”. Her name frequently appears in concert programs for about a ten year period. A later mezzo-soprano of the same name seems not to have been a relative." S. also photo in Alma record., August 29, 1918, Page 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85038709/1918-08-29/ed-...

March 4, 1922 in Rutgers Sports History rutgers.forums.rivals.com/threads/march-4-1922-in-rutgers... indicates that Ellis Enander, Fred Dettlinger and Bob Dornan were members of the Rutgers University football squad. 'In 1922, the Indianapolis Junior Chamber of Commerce extended invitations to nine major basketball college conferences. The Western Conference and Eastern Intercollegiate League declined. The tournament was played with Wabash defeating Kalamazoo 43-23 in the final. There would have been an eastern representative, but it was announced in the March 5, 1922 Sunday Times of New Brunswick, “Rutgers has declined the invitation to compete in the National Intercollegiate tournament which is to be held in Indianapolis, Indiana on March 9, 10 and 11. The faculty, in a special meeting held March 4, declined to approve a trip of such character and duration for the squad.”' Enander, who graduated in 1924 was also in the basketball squad, for all four years. See page 140 of s3.amazonaws.com/sidearm.sites/scarletknights.com/documen...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Shaughnessy,_1st_Baron_Shaug... Thomas George Shaughnessy, 1st Baron Shaughnessy KCVO (6 October 1853 – 10 December 1923) was an American-born Canadian railway administrator who rose from modest beginnings as a clerk and bookkeeper for the Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad (a predecessor of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad) to become the president of the Canadian Pacific Railway, serving in that capacity from 1899 to 1918. In recognition of his stewardship of the CPR and its contributions to the war effort during the Great War, Shaughnessy was elevated to the Peerage of the United Kingdom on 1 January 1916 as Baron Shaughnessy, of the City of Montreal in the Dominion of Canada and of Ashford in the County of Limerick.

popsicle sticks?

A similar photo ran in the 5 March 22 Evening Star noting that she was spending the day as a bellhop at the NY Biltmore Hotel raising funds for the Tuberculosis Relief Society. The "Popsicle Sticks" are in the form of the Cross of Lorraine - the symbol adopted for the "crusade" against Tuberculosis in the early 20th Century. The Tuberculosis Relief Society later morphed into the American Lung Association. [https://www.flickr.com/photos/drivingthenortheast/6167567934/]

I looked closer at the newspaper in the photo and recognized the image at the top of the page. It's a photo of the Knickerbocker Theater in DC after the roof collapsed on January 28, 1922. We have National Photo Co. negative taken from the same angle at www.loc.gov/pictures/resource/npcc.05700/. Some newspapers didn't run a full photo page until Sunday, but this confirms it was probably taken around the time of her first US concert.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malcolm_Wheeler-Nicholson "Malcolm Wheeler-Nicholson (January 7, 1890 – September 21, 1965) was an American pulp magazine writer and entrepreneur who pioneered the American comic book, publishing the first such periodical consisting solely of original material rather than reprints of newspaper comic strips. Long after his departure from the comic book company he founded, Wheeler-Nicholson's National Allied Publications would evolve into DC Comics, one of the U.S.'s two largest comic book publishers along with rival Marvel Comics."

Another photo of him ran in the Askov American. [volume], March 16, 1922, Image 7 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn89064914/1922-03-16/ed-... From wikipedia: "The Major's public criticism of Army command in an open letter to President Warren G. Harding, and his accusations against senior officers, led to countercharges, hearings, and a lawsuit against West Point Superintendent General Fred W. Sladen. Wheeler-Nicholson also was a victim of a shooting that his family called an Army-sanctioned assassination attempt. It left him hospitalized with a bullet wound. Following this, Wheeler-Nicholson in June 1922 was convicted in a court-martial trial of violating the 96th Article of War in publishing the open letter. Although he was not demoted, his career was dead-ended."

NYT of July 15, 1920 www.nytimes.com/1920/07/15/archives/famous-violinist-comi... reported that he was to come to the Egbert Conservatory in Ithaca, NY to teach for six months beginning January 1, 1921. William Egbert's conservatory became Ithaca College. See www.ithaca.edu/about/history

In a Czech language newspaper published in Ohio: Svět = World. An approximation to the article, with the help of Google Translate and some correction of the OCR is: New York, February 4. Last year in January arrived in the United States famous Czech paedagog violin playing, prof. Otokar Ševčík to accept the invitation of the American Conserve music tours in Ithaca, arrange the same violin high school course. The main reason prof. Sevčík to America, however, was that he wanted here to complete my life work that it is the only one of its kind the words of literature and look up content of the whole work It contains 17 bulky volumes! truly monumental, for it is dealt with in it about the art of playing violin not only on music, but also scientific. This work has been completed here and will be released in the autumn once local publishing company, in conjunction with the Simro World Music Race in Berlin. Prof. Sevčík left for his homeland today. Although it is 70 years old, it is strangely lively. He was arranged to say goodbye to him tumbler in the residence of the famous millionaire, Ralph Pulitzer, owner of "New York World!"

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peggy_Hopkins_Joyce "Peggy Hopkins Joyce (born Marguerite Upton; May 26, 1893 – June 12, 1957) was an American actress, artist's model and dancer. In addition to her performing career, Joyce was known for her flamboyant life, with numerous engagements, six marriages to wealthy men, subsequent divorces, a series of scandalous affairs, a collection of diamonds and furs, and a generally lavish lifestyle."

The Alexandria Gazette. February 10, 1922, Page 8 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85025007/1922-02-10/ed-... has a photo that may show the same hat. The caption reads, "Peggy Hopkins Joyce, actress and famous divorcee, has sailed for Europe to spend several months. While abroad she says that she will write her memoirs of her married life with her three millionaire husbands." So the date 2/7/22 on the negative may be the date she sailed. The Albuquerque Morning Journal. February 14, 1922, CITY EDITION, page 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84031081/1922-02-14/ed-... has a photo in what looks like the same fur coat. The accompanying article mentions that she sailed on the Aquitania.

Colonel Edward C. Gibbs The New-York tribune. [volume], February 05, 1922, Page 17, col. 7 (at bottom) reported that Gibbs, "an authority on contagious and infectious deseases", sailed on the steamer America for Bremen the day before. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1922-02-05/ed-... He returned in April 1922 on the same ship, s. Evening star. [volume], April 09, 1922, Page 2, col. 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1922-04-09/ed-... According to the New Ulm Post, February 17, 1922, Image 4, col. 2, Gibbs was superintendent of the New York City Board of Health chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85025556/1922-02-17/ed-...

Could be the Colonel Edward C. Gibbs mentioned in Medical Record, April 13, 1922 books.google.com/books?id=sDblAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA630&l... He had been to Poland to report on typhus conditions there. Journal of the American Medical Association, Vol 78, Issue 16, page 1209 books.google.com/books?id=w5ohAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA1209&... indicates that he returned on the America on April 7. This might have been taken when he sailed for Poland.

The [New York] Evening World. February 03, 1922, Final Edition, Page 13, column 3 (top) chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1922-02-03/ed-... reported that Gibbs was to sail for Poland on the America the next day. So this photo may be from Feb 4, 1922.

Presumably en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duncan_Sisters "The Duncan Sisters were an American vaudeville duo who became popular in the 1920s with their act Topsy and Eva." Rosetta (November 23, 1894 – December 4, 1959) and Vivian Duncan (June 17, 1897 – September 19, 1986) See also www.streetswing.com/histmai2/d2topsy_eva1.htm utc.iath.virginia.edu/onstage/duncanhp.html www.freewebs.com/looking-for-mabel/duncan.htm utc.iath.virginia.edu/interpret/exhibits/sullivan/sulliva... A search for "Duncan sisters" photos at LoC www.loc.gov/pictures/search/?q=%22duncan%20sisters%22&... reveals more Bain photos (not yet uploaded to Flickr) of the same duo, but also suggests that there may have been another group (a trio) given the same name by Bain.

Trying to date the voyage: According to Vaudeville old & new: an encyclopedia of variety performances in America books.google.ca/books?id=XFnfnKg6BcAC&pg=PA337&lp... they went to London in 1921 and came back to the U.S. by 1922. This photo is probably from one of the associated voyages to or from England, assuming this photo is in the general time frame of most of the nearby photos in the Bain stream. The Pueblo Chieftain., May 21, 1921, Page 8 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn90051672/1921-05-21/ed-... has a picture of them "ready to sail for Europe," probably taken on a ship (unidentified). The London Stage 1920-1929: A Calendar of Productions, Performers, and Personnel books.google.ca/books?id=5vFEAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA94&lpg... indicates that their London debut was on June 1, 1921. See double spread in The Washington Times, January 08, 1922, about meeting the Prince of Wales in England chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1922-01-08/ed-... chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1922-01-08/ed-... But, so far, I haven't found any indication of when they returned from England. The New York herald, May 23, 1922, Page 8, top of column 6 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045774/1922-05-23/ed-... indicates that they were booked to sail for Europe again on the Aquitania that day.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margot_Asquith "Emma Margaret Asquith, Countess of Oxford and Asquith (née Tennant; 2 February 1864 – 28 July 1945), known as Margot Asquith, was a British socialite, author, and wit. She was married to H. H. Asquith, Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, from 1894 until his death in 1928." In 1922, she published "My Impressions of America" books.google.ca/books?id=PxeyDwAAQBAJ

www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/portrait/mw292996/Margo...? Looks to be in the same outfit and also originating from Bain (digitized from a bromide print rather than a glass negative). It is dated 2 February 1922. I think the location of this photo can be seen at the right of the NPG photo. A search for "Asquith" at LoC, www.loc.gov/pictures/search/?q=asquith&sp=1&st=ga... yields a couple of pictures from the National Photo Company Collection from February 15, 1922 www.loc.gov/pictures/search/?q=asquith&co=npco&st... She's wearing the same coat. [Aside: The little girl with Margot Asquith in the NPCC pictures is Margot's grand-daughter, Priscilla, the daughter of en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elizabeth_Bibesco. The NPG has pictures of Priscilla too; see www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person/mp55479/princess... ] I hypothesize that this Bain photo was taken in New York (or possibly Washington DC) on 2/2/1922 (the date scribbled on the negative). Margot's daughter Elizabeth's husband was the Romanian ambassador to the U.S. from 1920 to 1926.

A different photo of Amundsen and these two girls dressed in the same outfits as in this rooftop photo appeared in the January 14, 1922, Richmond (Ind.) Palladium with the following article: "Capt. Roald Amundsen, famous for the discovery of the South Pole and for various Arctic exploits, is now in Washington with two Siberian children whom he brought back with him from his recent trip through the Northwest Passage. According to friends, Amundsen will send them to Christiania, Norway, to be educated. They are Cakonita, eight-years-old, and Camille, twelve-years-old. Amundsen found them near the coast of Wrangell Land. During his last trip, Capt. Amundsen encountered unprecedented ice jams which made such trouble that his ship was pinned in the ice near Cape Serge on the northern coast of Siberia. There he came into contact with native tribes, eking a precarious living by hunting and fishing. One of the little girls came first to his attention because she was starving. Amundsen took care of the children and fed and clothed them. They were so responsive he soon became greatly attached to them and before he left he obtained permission of their parents to adopt them."

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roald_Amundsen "Roald Engelbregt Gravning Amundsen (UK: /ˈɑːmʊndsən/, US: /-məns-/; 16 July 1872 – c. 18 June 1928) was a Norwegian explorer of polar regions and a key figure of the Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration. He led the first expedition to traverse the Northwest Passage by sea, from 1903 to 1906, and the first expedition to the South Pole in 1911. He led the first expedition proven to have reached the North Pole in 1926. He disappeared while taking part in a rescue mission for the airship Italia in 1928." "During the third winter, Maud was frozen in the western Bering Strait. She finally became free and the expedition sailed south, reaching Seattle, in the American Pacific Northwest in 1921 for repairs. Amundsen returned to Norway, needing to put his finances in order. He took with him two young indigenous girls, a four-year-old he adopted, Kakonita, and her companion Camilla. When Amundsen went bankrupt two years later, however, he sent the girls to be cared for by Camilla's father, who lived in eastern Russia."

"Le roi d'Ys (The King of Ys) is an opera in three acts and five tableaux by the French composer Édouard Lalo, to a libretto by Édouard Blau, based on the old Breton legend of the drowned city of Ys. " "The work received its American premiere at the French Opera House in New Orleans on 23 January 1890, but it was not until 1922 that it was finally staged at the Metropolitan Opera. The Metropolitan premiere starred Rosa Ponselle as Margared, Beniamino Gigli as Mylio, and Frances Alda as Rozenn. With declining interest in romantic and lyric operas after World War I, however, when works of such previously popular composers as Massenet or Reyer suffered, the opera received tepid reviews[5] and ran for just six performances en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Le_roi_d%27Ys"; From the Met Archive: archives.metoperafamily.org/archives/scripts/cgiip.exe/WS... Pictured is Beniamino Gigli, opera singer. See Victor notation at top refers to Bain's contract with Victor, and probably to Gigli's Victor recording from Le Roi d'Ys in March, 1922: adp.library.ucsb.edu/index.php/matrix/detail/800000086/B-...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aureliano_Pertile "Aureliano Pertile (9 November 1885, Montagnana - 11 January 1952, Milan) was an Italian lyric-dramatic tenor. Many critics consider him one of the most exciting operatic artists of the inter-war period, and one of the most important tenors of the 20th century." "Pertile made his New York Metropolitan Opera debut as Cavaradossi in Tosca, with Maria Jeritza in the title role, on 1 December 1921. In his only season at the Met, his other roles included des Grieux in Manon Lescaut, Turiddu in Cavalleria rusticana, Grigori in Boris Godunov (with Feodor Chaliapin), Radames in Aida, the title role in Pagliacci (opposite Florence Easton), and Julien in Louise (opposite Geraldine Farrar). He also participated in performances of Louise with the Met's touring company at Philadelphia and in Brooklyn." See also archives.metoperafamily.org/Imgs/PertileTosca.htm

For those who may not know, Mackenzie King was the  10th Prime Minister of Canada

"William Lyon Mackenzie King OM, CMG, PC (December 17, 1874 – July 22, 1950), also commonly known as Mackenzie King, was the dominant Canadian political leader from the 1920s through the 1940s. He served as the tenth prime minister of Canada in 1921–1926, 1926–1930 and 1935–1948. He is best known for his leadership of Canada throughout the Second World War (1939–1945) when he mobilized Canadian money, supplies and volunteers to support Britain while boosting the economy and maintaining morale on the home front. " en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Lyon_Mackenzie_King

See music.metason.net/artistinfo?name=International Novelty... www.discogs.com/artist/1541489-International-Novelty-Orch... "In the United States, The International Novelty Orchestra was a pseudonym for the Victor house band conducted by Victor's musical director Nathaniel Shilkret in the Victor studios. The pseudonym was first used in March 1922. Brian Rust published the session data for US recordings in his 'American Dance Band Discography'. Between 1922 and 1927, a total of 135 tracks were recorded; 36 of these were rejected and 99 were released on Victor in the USA. Seventeen different vocalists were used but many tracks had no vocals. " For recordings, see www.loc.gov/jukebox/artists/detail/id/13/

For some more background, see www.allmusic.com/artist/nathaniel-shilkret-mn0000381949/b... "Nathaniel "Nat" Shilkret was born in Queens and came up through the ranks of New York's then-numerous community orchestras as a "boy wonder" clarinetist; he also played violin and piano and took lessons with George Gershwin's teacher, Charles Hambitzer. By the time Shilkret was 18, he was a member of the New York Philharmonic; he would also play with the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra and in Arthur Pryor's Band. In 1915, Shilkret began working for Victor as an arranger and conductor, yet did not earn a credit on records until 1921 when he teamed with drummer and Victor executive Eddie King to form the Shilking Orchestra. The silly name was retired after only three records, but the basic 8-10 musicians who made up the Shilking continued on under Shilkret's direction, producing numerous popular music selections to suit Victor's various needs. Aided by guest performers and filled out by sidemen, the Shilking appeared on Victor Records as the Great White Way Orchestra, the Manhattan Merrymakers, the Troubadours, Victor Salon Orchestra, International Novelty Orchestra, Hilo Hawaiian Orchestra, All-Star Orchestra, and so on. The device Shilkret and the Victor Orchestra didn't appear on records until the release of "Barcelona," a novelty hit with a Billy Murray vocal, in 1926."

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Davidson_(producer) "Paul Davidson (30 March 1867 – 18 July 1927) was a German film producer." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_Lubitsch "Ernst Lubitsch (/ˈluːbɪtʃ/; January 29, 1892 – November 30, 1947) was a German American film director, producer, writer, and actor. His urbane comedies of manners gave him the reputation of being Hollywood's most elegant and sophisticated director; as his prestige grew, his films were promoted as having "the Lubitsch touch". Among his best known works are Trouble in Paradise, Design for Living, Ninotchka, The Shop Around the Corner, To Be or Not to Be and Heaven Can Wait." "Lubitsch sailed to the United States for the first time in December 1921 for what was intended as a lengthy publicity and professional factfinding tour, scheduled to culminate in the February premiere of Pharaoh. However, with World War I still fresh, and with a slew of German "New Wave" releases encroaching on American movie workers' livelihoods, Lubitsch was not gladly received. He cut his trip short after little more than three weeks and returned to Germany. "

They arrived on December 24, 1921 on the America. "Both Mr. Lubitsch and Mr. Davidson are coming to America under the auspices of the Hamilton Theatrical Corporation to study American methods of film production." New-York tribune. [volume], December 25, 1921, Page 4, Image 40, col. 4 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1921-12-25/ed-...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armando_Diaz "Armando Diaz, 1st Duke of the Victory, OSSA, OSML, OMS, OCI (5 December 1861 – 28 February 1928) was an Italian general and a Marshal of Italy. He is mostly known for his role as Chief of Staff of the Regio Esercito during World War I since November 1917. He managed to stop the Austro-Hungarian advance along the Piave River in the Battle of Monte Grappa, and in June 1918 led the Italian forces to a major victory in the Battle of the Piave River. A few months later, he achieved a decisive victory in the Battle of Vittorio Veneto, which ended the war on the Italian Front. He is celebrated as one of the greatest generals of World War I." In April 1927, according to the [Washington DC] Evening Star., April 17, 1927, Image 97 (with picture of same ruins) chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1927-04-17/ed-... under a concession by the Panama government, an English and American group was hunting for treasure in the ruins of the San Jose Church, where gold and other treasure was supposed to have been buried when the British buccaneer, Sir Henry Morgan, plundered the city in 1671. Evening star. March 12, 1927, Page 14 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1927-03-12/ed-... identified George Williams, an Englishman, as one of the team that had discovered "golden ornaments and chains tarnished by long burial and precious stones, including emeralds, rubies, diamonds and sapphires."

Another contemporary account: "Lieut. George Williams and Fred Kelley, Englishmen, and Wallace Bain, and American, recently uncovered valuable gold relics and gems beneath the ruins of the San Jose Convent. " msgw.org/tishomingo/BelmontTimesApr151927.pdf

Williams is further identified as British Naval Reserve in this 1927 Popular Radio article about the search, which focuses on radio equipment used in the treasure hunt: "Some months ago there came to Pan-ama Lieutenant George Williams of the British Naval Reserves; with him are Commander David Blair and Lieutenant F. W. Really. both of England, and Mr. Wallace Bain, of the United States. Another member of the expedition is a piece of radio apparatus, said to be the invention of Mr. Thomas Fahie, of Colchester, England. Using this radio apparatus, Lieutenant Williams is attempting to locate some of the buried hoards of precious metal. " www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Popular-Radio/Popula... pp. 224-226

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Titta_Ruffo 'Titta Ruffo (9 June 1877 – 5 July 1953), born as Ruffo Cafiero (double forename) Titta, was an Italian operatic baritone who had a major international singing career. Known as the "Voce del leone" ("voice of the lion"), he was greatly admired, even by rival baritones, such as Giuseppe De Luca, who said of Ruffo: "His was not a voice, it was a miracle" (although not often published is the second part of De Luca's conclusion "which he [Ruffo] bawled away..."), and Victor Maurel, the creator of Verdi's Iago and Falstaff. Maurel said that the notes of Ruffo's upper register were the most glorious baritone sounds he had ever heard (see Pleasants, cited below). Indeed Walter Legge, the prominent classical record producer, went so far as to call Ruffo "a genius". ' We saw him in the Bain stream 11 years ago!

St. Michael. Presented by Gen'l Diaz to the American Legion in Kansas City (not Monte Grappa) see: www.legion.org/museum/st-michael
A gift from General Armando Diaz, commander of Italian forces in the First World War. Presented at The American Legion's 3rd Annual National Convention in Kansas City. Inscription reads: A LA LEGIONE AMERICANA ED AI SUOI UFFICIALI E MEMBRI CHE HANNO COMBATTUTO CON VALORE SUI SANGUINOSI CAMPI DI BATTAGLIA DELLA GRANDE GUERRA A FIANCO DEI SOLDATI DÃƒ, ITALIA CON MEMORE AFFETO DI CAMERATA IL GENERALE DIAZ ROMA OTTOBRE 1921 "To The American Legion and to its officials and members, who fought with valor on the bloody battlefields of the Great War at the side of the soldiers of Italy. With affectionate memory of comradeship. General Diaz, Rome, October 1921" The statue portrays St. Michael, the archangel, sheathing his sword. The image is a portrayal of an event in 590 AD when the city of Rome was afflicted by plague. Pope Gregory the Great led a procession to pray for the end of the plague. At the end of the procession, the Pope witnessed St. Michael appearing on the top of Hadrian's Tomb. The archangel's sheathing of his sword was a sign of the removal of God's wrath and the end of the plague. As a gift from the veterans of Italy, the apparition of Michael ending the plague is a symbolic representation of the entry of the United States into the Great War signaling the end of that great calamity.

The New-York tribune. [volume], November 27, 1921, Graphic Section, Image 67 printed a cropped version of this photo with the caption: "GENERAL DIAZ' GIFT TO THE AMERICAN LEGION. A replica of the famous Mount Grappa statue which General Diaz brought from Italy as a gift to the American Legion and which was presented to the Legion at their recent Kansas City convention. The replica is mounted on a stone base taken from the original statue." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1921-11-27/ed-... Mount Grappa refers to the battles of Monte Grappa en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Monte_Grappa

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05] I have to wonder if some of the story didn't get lost in translation/transmission.  I haven't been able to find any statues of St. Michael associated with Monte Grappa.  My guess is that the base is a rock from Grappa, where an important battle took place and a large ossuarium was built, and maybe even the plaque is a replica of one installed at Grappa, but the statue is a copy of a famous one atop Castel Sant'angelo in Rome.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/tammyrinaldi/4643897747]

Washington Evening Star , March 3, 1930 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1930-03-03/ed-...
Air Pioneer Succumbs Phil Ringel is Third Victim of Crash at Marietta, Ga. CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 3 Us). —Phil (Jersey) Ringel, pioneer aviator and stunt flyer, died at a hospital here last night, the third victim of a Marietta, Ga., air crash last Monday. | Ringel was piloting a plane bearing George Tarbell Patten, president of Southern Fliers. Inc., and Dr. Lyle B. West, Patten’s family physician, to the bedside of Patten’s wife, who was lnjured in an automobile accident in Clearwater, Fla. Poor visibility, Ringel said, caused him to misjudge the field and he crashed after going Into a nose dive approximately 100 feet in the air. Mr. Patten was instantly killed. Dr West died In an Atlanta hospital.
Flying a Curtiss JN-4 "Canuck" - the Canadian version of the US "Jenny"

Queensbury's still "Lake George" to a lot of people. This is at the southern "pole" of the tourist area across from (what is now) Six Flags' Great Escape. North of here  is the strip of factory outlets at the I-87/US-9/NY-149 intersection where the roads bringing people from Albany/NYC, Montreal and Vermont converge. North of *that* is Lake George itself.

South of here are a few small attractions but you get pretty quickly into generic non-touristy suburbia of Glens Falls.

"Fannie Hurst (October 19, 1885 – February 23, 1968] was an American novelist and short-story writer whose works were highly popular during the post-World War I era. Her work combined sentimental, romantic themes with social issues of the day, such as women's rights and race relations. She was one of the most widely read female authors of the 20th century, and for a time in the 1920s she was one of the highest-paid American writers, along with Booth Tarkington. Hurst also actively supported a number of social causes, including feminism, African American equality, and New Deal programs." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fannie_Hurst

"Yajima Kajiko (矢嶋 楫子, 1833 – June 16, 1925) was the founder of the Women's Reform Society and president of Japan's Woman's Christian Temperance Union. An educator, pacifist, and Christian activist, she vigorously advanced the cause for the education of women in Japan. Her name was usually seen as Kaji Yajima in the American press of her day. [...] Her 1921 visit to the United States was covered by many American newspapers and magazines; she took the opportunity to express her hopes for world peace: "When I am gone, remember that I stood here looking into your faces expressing the hope that you will do all that is in your power as this old body will, that the world may know peace from now on. We have come to the time when we not only want peace, but know we must have it."[19] In her message to the "Christian women of America", Kaji Yajima assured her audience that "the women of Japan want education, not battleships or armies. They want the government to spend money, not on military establishments, but on schools."" en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yajima_Kajiko
Picture is dated 12/2/1921. She spoke at Town Hall in New York on November 30, and immediately began her return to Japan. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1921-12-01/ed-...
Thanks,  [https://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog] , for all the great biographical information! We'll be sure to add some to the record.

"Prince Iemasa Tokugawa (徳川 家正 Tokugawa Iemasa, March 23, 1884 – February 18, 1963) also known as Iyemasa, was a Japanese political figure of the Taishō and early Shōwa periods. He was the 17th hereditary head of the former shogunal branch of the Tokugawa clan and the final President of the House of Peers in the Diet of Japan." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iemasa_Tokugawa

The Richmond palladium and sun-telegram. [volume], October 01, 1921, Image 1, col. 3 reported: "Prince Tokugawa's son, Iyemasa Tokugawa, has arrived from Peking, where he was secretary at the Japanese legation and will accompany his father across the Pacific, being en route to London to which city he has been transferred. It is probable he will visit Washington en route." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86058226/1921-10-01/ed-...
His wife Naoko Shimazu was a daughter of Shimazu Tadayoshi (島津忠義, May 22, 1840 – December 26, 1897) en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shimazu_Tadayoshi_(2nd)

This is a lame, misguided depiction of primitive humans. By the time early homo sapiens lost most of their body hair, (and these three appear to have almost none except perhaps pubic hair in the groin region), they began wearing animal skins and other forms of clothing to cover up the titillating parts and "naughty bits". That was a matter of practicality and a logical, rational reaction to the naked human form. The part that baffles me is why a bad, ill-conceived piece of supposed art such as this exists in the collection of the Library of Congress, and how it got in there in the first place. Very simply it is bad art.

More Tokorozawa:

The airplanes are either WWI surplus French Salmson 2.A2s or Japanese Army Otsu-1s. Japanese production of the planes under license from Salmson began at Tokorozawa in 1921 (and later by Kawasaki in 1922) but I think these might be examples of French built planes - note the "2A2" in Romaji on the planes' rudders. Normally 2 seaters, it looks like the observers' seats are covered over, maybe in bomber configuration? Possibly related to the Traveltown Motor Court. From "ARCHITECTURAL SURVEY OF BOTETOURT COUNTY, VIRGINIA" from December 31, 2008 www.dhr.virginia.gov/pdf_files/SpecialCollections/BO-059_... "Traveltown Motor Court (011-5295). The original building began ca. 1930 with a main dining area, swimming pool, and 18 separate cottages. The small cottages were later relocated throughout the Cloverdale area when the complex was updated around 1950 and the current two-story motel was built. The construction of Interstate Highway 81 to the northwest in the early 1980s took away the traffic from Route 11, and the motel has been vacant since the 1985 flood."

From www.stjosephmemorylane.com/eatingm-z/eatingm-z.html Snow White Restaurant 1520 Frederick Avenue building no longer exists SNOW WHITE RESTAURANT 3645 Frederick Avenue "Snow White was located on the Belt Highway just north of Frederick Avenue The Snow White was remodeled shortly after 1957 By the late-1950's Snow White had expanded and become the largest and most popular drive-in restaurant in St Joseph Snow White as the home of the 59 cent Big'un!, a big double decker cheeseburger with a special sauce Every booth had a small juke box player. For a quarter you could listen to 5 songs Their pies were made by Jerre Anne's, who made the best pies in St Joseph In the mid 1960's, the curb service closed, only inside eating was provided I was at the curb service one night, I observed some kids were getting out of hand squirting mustard and ketchup The curb service was closed down permanently the very next day - this may have been the reason On January 25, 1991, the Snow White was razed Shortly after, Winsteads Hamburgers was constructed on the site Winsteads was torn down about a year later Winsteads was replaced with a Walgreen Pharmacy"

Adolf Lorenz (21 April 1854 – 12 February 1946), Austrian orthopedic surgeon en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adolf_Lorenz

Charlotte Beck was operated on by Lorenz when she was a child, s. The evening world. [volume], December 19, 1902, Night Edition, Image 1, last col., "Walks Within One Week" chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1902-12-19/ed-...

The New York Tribune ran another photo of Lorenz on December 4, 1921 with the caption: DR. ADOLF LORENZ, famous orthopedic surgeon of Vienna, returns to this country after an absence of eighteen years and begins a series of plastic operations, practically all his patients being children. Our picture shows the modern miracle worker at work on a boy's arm at St. Marks Hospital. In striking contrast to Dr. Lorenz' former visit, when because of his high fees, his services were available only to the wealthy, the surgeon is giving his time and talent free to the poor in gratitude for America's aid to Austria's children. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1921-12-04/ed-...

The Hospital for Deformities and Joint Diseases was located at 1919 Madison Avenue in Harlem. The building no longer stands. It was across the street from Mount Morris Park (now Marcus Garvey Park). The hospital dispensary was aound the corner at 41-43 East 123rd St. According to the NY Charities Directory the dispensary treated 500-700 patients daily (1/4 of them polio victims).
A story about crowds of children seeking treatment with Lorenz turned away: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1921-12-13/ed-...

The aerial bombing trials of 1923 conducted by General Billy Mitchell (USAAS), which saw the destruction of USS Virginia (BB-13) as a target ship in September 1923. Virginia, commissioned in 1906, was long obsolete and slated for sale and scrapping under the terms of the Washington Naval Treaty. Instead of being sold for scrap, she was eliminated from the fleet during the aforementioned bombing trials. Here is footage of Virginia being bombed and ultimately sunk (see beginning at the 10min 58sec mark): YouTube - US National Archives: Aerial Bombing of Ships (1921-1923) - (National Archives Identifier: 24624 - Local Identifier: 111-H-1119)

Marcelle Picard (note sp.) was an American/French society girl. She attended the Rayson School for Girls (NYC) and studied piano under Louis Stillman before moving to France ~1921. In 1923 she married Ignacio de Coll Castell, heir to a Spanish brewing conglomerate (Damm, brewers of La Bohemia) and moved to Barcelona. Then her life got complicated. She may be of current interest because of the legal wranglings surrounding citizenship of her son Fernando Coll Picard. As quoted on Leagle.com in the opinion on a later case . . .
In the case of Fernando Jorge Coll y Picard the opinion of the Attorney General of the United States (37 Op.Atty. Gen. 90) concerned a child born in Spain in 1927 to a native American woman who had been married in 1923 to a Spanish citizen and returned to the United States with her minor child and secured a divorce in 1931 and the decree awarded her custody of the child. It was the determination of the Attorney General that the child in that case had derived United States citizenship under the provisions of Section 5 of the Act of March 2, 1907, 34 Stat. 1229, which provided that a child born without the United States of alien parents shall be deemed a citizen by virtue of the naturalization of or resumption of American citizenship by the parent, provided such naturalization or resumption takes place during the minority of the child, the citizenship to begin at the time such minor child begins to reside permanently in the United States. The Attorney General wrote: While under Section 5 of that statute Congress is dealing with cases of resumption of American citizenship, there seems to be no good reason for supposing that the Congress intended to decline to grant citizenship to the minor child merely because its mother never lost her American citizenship, having married after the effective date of the Act of 1922 [42 Stat. 1022]. I think, therefore, that so far as the citizenship of her children is concerned, Mrs. de Coll should be treated as in precisely the same situation as one who had resumed her citizenship.
She later married Joseph Marshall Haight of Philadelphia (died 1965) and, in 1966, married Theodore Tweedy White, Jr. in NY.

As much as I hate to feed the troll . . . the fuller and original quote (by the Duke of Gloucester (Richard III) from Henry VI, Part III) is
I, that have neither pity, love, nor fear. Indeed, 'tis true that Henry told me of; For I have often heard my mother say I came into the world with my legs forward: Had I not reason, think ye, to make haste, And seek their ruin that usurp'd our right? The midwife wonder'd and the women cried 'O, Jesus bless us, he is born with teeth!' And so I was; which plainly signified That I should snarl and bite and play the dog. Then, since the heavens have shaped my body so, Let hell make crook'd my mind to answer it. I have no brother, I am like no brother; And this word 'love,' which graybeards call divine, Be resident in men like one another And not in me: I am myself alone.

The poster on the wall is an advertisement for a Yiddish play starring David Kessler at the Second Street Theater.  The play was entitled "The God of Vengence" and was about a man living, with his wife and daughter, above the brothel that he owns.  He wants to keep his daughter pure, but eventually, she is drawn to becoming a prostitute and falls in love with one of the other girls.  Pretty racy for the times.  When the play was translated into English in the 1920's, the producer and cast were arrested after a performance and put on trial and found guilty on obscenity charges.

Tower is a radio antenna at RCA "Radio Central" at Rocky Point, Long Island, see
RCA "Radio Central" at Rocky Point, Long Island, see

This photo was published in 1922 in The Book of Radio, Charles William Taussig, pages 312-327, to illustrate a chapter on the opening of "Radio Central" Radio Corporation of America's (RCA) at Rocky Point, Long Island. earlyradiohistory.us/1922RCA.htm The Rocky Point Historical Society website account: "In July of 1920, RCA began construction of their main Operating and Administration Building #1. It was built in mediterranean architecture of cream-colored walls, with brick trim, accented with arched windows and an overhanging roof of ceramic red tiles. A large wooden door, trimmed with studded nail heads and a carved brass handle, opened into an entrance hall. On November 5, 1921 President Warren C. Harding pressed a button in the White House in Washington, D.C. which officially opened the RCA Radio Central facilities at Rocky Point. Radio Central was considered the largest transmitting station in the world. Originally, long waves were used, resulting in the construction of six 410 high steel towers. The towers were 410’ high with added cross-arm of 40’ high, extending the total height to 450’. The tall height of the structures was necessary for the long distance, worldwide type of radio communications. The twelve towers, which were 1260 apart, covered a two and a half mile area. Tower #1 remained standing tall, with its flashing red beacon guiding planes and ships, served as an aviation beacon light for another sixteen years. AT 2:30 PM on December 13, 1977, the 56-year-old tower was the last to come down." www.rockypointhistoricalsociety.org/rca-radio-central/
These are actually radio antennae at RCA "Radio Central" at Rocky Point, Long Island, see

Here is someone's transcription of his obituary from a genealogy message board: "SIR JOHN JOYCE BRODERICK IT WAS ONLY IN JANUARY LAST THAT SIR JOHN JOYCE BRODERICK, K.B.E., WHO SINCE 1931 HAD BEEN HIS MAJESTY'S ENVOY EXTRAORDINARY AND MINISTER PLENIPOTENTIARY TO THE REPUBLIC OF CUBA, WAS ANOINTED AMBASSADOR TO ARGENTINA, WHERE HIS FELLOW-CATHOLICS LOOKED TOWARD TO HIS PRESENCE AMONG THEM AT BUENOS AIRES NEXT YEAR AS ONE OF THE MANY CATHOLIC NOTABILITIES ATTENDING THE EUCHARISTIC CONGRESS. BEFORE TAKING UP HIS NEW DUTIES, SIR JOHN WAS SPENDING A HOLIDAY WITH LADY BRODERICK, IN ENGLAND. ILLNESS OVERTOOK HIM AND HE DIED ON FRIDAY, LAST WEEK, IN A NURSING HOME IN LONDON, AT THE AGE OF FIFTY ONE. SIR M.G. JOHN BRODERICK WAS THE SON OF THE LATE MICHAEL BRODERICK, OF RYEHILL, COUNTY GALWAY. HE HAD HIS EDUCATION AT BLACKROCK COLLEGE, DUBLIN, AND AT THE ROYAL UNIVERSITY, AFTERWARDS ENTERING THE CUSTOMS SERVICE, IN WHICH HE REMAINED UNTIL. 1908. IN THAT YEAR HE BEGAN A CAREER IN THE CONSULAR SERVICE, AND HELD THE POSTS, SUCCESSIVELY, OF VICE-CONSUL AT NEW YORK, CONSUL AT BARCELONA, ACTING CONSUL GENERAL AT ROTTERDAM AND LATER AT NEW YORK, ASSISTANT COMMERCIAL ADVISER TO THE BRITISH EMBASSY AT WASHINGTON, COMMERCIAL SECRETARY AND COMMERCIAL COUNSELOR. THE HONOR OF C.M.G. WAS CONFERRED UPON HIM IN 1925, AND TWO YEARS LATER HE RECEIVED A KNIGHTHOOD IN THE ORDER OF THE BRITISH EMPIRE. SIR JOHN HAD THE DISTINCTION OF BEING THE FIRST MEMBER OF THE COMMERCIAL DIPLOMATIC SERVICE TO BE GIVEN-THOUGH HE DID NOT LIVE TO FILL IT-THE POST OF AMBASSADOR. HE HAS DIED ON THE THRESHOLD OF WHAT HAD APPEARED TO BE THE PROMISE OF A LONG AND DISTINGUISHED PERIOD OF SERVICE IN THIS HIGHER RANK OF DIPLOMACY,FOR WHICH HE HAD SHOWN HIMSELF FITTED BY CONSPICUOUS SUCCESS IN THE EARLIER PATH. HE HAD KNOWLEDGE,TACT,geniality, THREE QUALITIES ALMOST ESSENTIAL IN DIPLOMATIC LIFE. THE FUNERAL TOOK PLACE ON MONDAY LAST AT DEANS GRANGE CEMETERY, CO. DUBLIN. AT THE GRAVESIDE THE COMMITTAL PRAYERS WERE RECITED BY FATHER T. P. kelly, brother in law to the deceased. LADY BRODERICK IS A DAUGHTER OF THE LATE EDWARD KELLY, OF BLACKROCK. www.ancestry.com/boards/surnames.calligan/11.3.1.1.1.2.1....

"The London String Quartet was a string quartet founded in London in 1908 which remained one of the leading English chamber groups into the 1930s, and made several well-known recordings." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London_String_Quartet

It appears that the London String Quartet and the Flonzaley Quartet both came to NY on the same sailing of the RMS Carmania. This must have been fascinating. Several writers have compared the two quartets. A January 1922 article in The Musician reads (in part)
Here in this English organization is a worthy rival of our Flonzaleys. Many indeed do not draw the comparison as meekly as that but give blunt preference the Londoners. They have not, perhaps, the absolute finish and gloss that lies over the style of the Flonzaleys, but they are four interesting individual artists, enthusiastic, poetic, lively.
Or, according to Irving Kolodin (as quoted on the LSQ wiki page)
'In the Flonzaley's later years,... they seemed to have become a committee of experts matching exquisite swatches of tonal texture rather than performers of music. For young ears, the rise of the London String Quartet (with the incomparable James Levey as leader, and the enduring partnership of Thomas Petre, H. Waldo Warner and C. Warwick Evans participating) dimmed the Flonzaley star even as it was waning. A more vibrant enthusiasm, a stronger sense of tonal colours, a refinement that was not raffiné, gave them pre-eminence as long as this personnel endured.

Claire Dux (1885-1967), Soprano. Originally from Germany, and with a successful European career, in 1921 she joined the Chicago Civic Opera. She performed at the Met on November 29, 1921 with the New York Philharmonic being conducted by Richard Strauss (whose own arrival that month was also documented in this batch of Bain photos). Interestingly, the NY Trib refers to that performance as her "American Debut" while others note her earlier work with the Chicago Opera. The implication being that if it isn't in New York (preferably at the Met) it doesn't really count. Interestingly, Dux was under contract with Milton Diamond's International Concert Direction, the same agent who arranged Strauss' tour. see [https://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/40475920283/]

Mary Garden, 1874-1967. Scottish/American Operatic Soprano and Giorgio Polacco, 1873-1960, Italian opera conductor, aboard the RMS Aquitania on their way to shake up the Chicago Opera scene. from his allmusic.com bio . . .
After that first Chicago season, engagements in France, Cuba, and South America kept the conductor busy until Mary Garden called him in 1921 to become music director and principal conductor of the Chicago Opera, reorganized as the Chicago Civic Opera. Working with the tempestuous Garden, Polacco -- despite several voluble conflicts with his "directa" -- filled the position more than honorably. From the November 14, 1921, production of Samson et Dalila through the time of his retirement for health reasons in 1930, the conductor concentrated on his work in Chicago, conducting just one year (1927) in Boston. During his Chicago tenure, Polacco confirmed his outstanding grasp of a wide-ranging repertory and an unflagging ability to light fires under nearly any cast. He often conducted Garden, notably in her French repertory and in Strauss' Salome. Polacco's final Chicago performance found him leading Garden's Mélisande on February 1, 1930.
For more on Garden see [https://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3066027708/]

Ernest Manifold Raeburn, KBE 1878-1922. Sir Ernest was the former Director General of the British Ministry of Shipping.  He sailed on the SS Olympic for New York from London in October 1921.  While in the US he was leading negotiations regarding payment for shipping costs during WWI (ex: the UK billed the US $32mil for transporting soldiers across the Atlantic, the US billed the UK $20mil for transporting oil during the war - it got complicated). 

Unfortunately, while still in the US on this mission, he came down with a cold in June 1922 which turned into double pneumonia and he died, age 43, in New York.  His body was returned to the UK on SS Olympic, the same ship on which he arrived.

www.thepeerage.com/p55424.htm#i554240 He arrived in New York on the Olympic on October 11, 1921, s. The New York herald., October 12, 1921, Page 9, col. 4 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045774/1921-10-12/ed-...

"Christitch, Annie, 1885-1977 English journalist and author. Christitch's father was of Serbian descent. Her Mother, Elizabeth O'Brien Christitch, wrote under the name "Ben Hurst." Annie Christitch was active in Catholic circles, efforts to improve social conditions in Serbia, and the women's movement. From the description of Annie and Elizabeth O'Brien Christitch Papers, 1879-1977, (bulk 1910-1940). (Boston College). WorldCat record id: 32502763" snaccooperative.org/ark:/99166/w60p384z#biography

"On the Eastern Front in Serbia, the lecturer, religious writer and Catholic suffragist Annie Christitch (1885-1977) reported for British papers during 1915 to 1918. Christitch, a Serbian national with an Irish mother, who had been educated and was mainly living in the United Kingdom, was sent to Serbia as a staff correspondent of the Daily Express. In Valjevo she established a relief centre and was in charge of eight hospitals during the occupation of Serbia by German and Austrian forces. Due to her Serbian nationality, she was allowed to stay in Serbia when all foreigners were expelled. Her articles on the plight of the Serbian war victims appeared in the Daily Express and other British publications and were reprinted in newspapers in Australia, New Zealand and China. Moreover, the British and foreign press reported extensively about her relief work in Serbia." encyclopedia.1914-1918-online.net/article/women_war_repor...

"Armando Diaz, 1st Duke of the Victory, OSSA, OSML, OMS, OCI (5 December 1861 – 28 February 1928) was an Italian general and a Marshal of Italy. He is mostly known for his role as Chief of Staff of the Regio Esercito during World War I since November 1917. He managed to stop the Austro-Hungarian advance along the Piave River in the Battle of Monte Grappa, and in June 1918 led the Italian forces to a major victory in the Battle of the Piave River. A few months later, he achieved a decisive victory in the Battle of Vittorio Veneto, which ended the war on the Italian Front. He is celebrated as one of the greatest generals of World War I." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armando_Diaz He sailed to America on the SS Giuseppi Verdi in October, 1921 to speak at the American Legion conference that year. timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1921/10/07/98750667...

Oct. 1, 1921. Columbia 7, Amherst 9 Prior to 1928 Football games at Columbia were played on the south lawn in front of Low Memorial Library (partially visible on left of pic). The dome center left is St. Pauls Chapel with Buell Hall (still the oldest building on the campus) in front of it by the flag pole. The larger buildings center right are Kent Hall (left) and Hamilton Hall (right) and a little bit of Hartley Hall is visible far right. All still standing. Current Street View

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roscoe_Arbuckle "Roscoe Conkling "Fatty" Arbuckle (/ˈɑːrbʌkəl/; March 24, 1887 – June 29, 1933) was an American silent film actor, comedian, director, and screenwriter. Starting at the Selig Polyscope Company he eventually moved to Keystone Studios, where he worked with Mabel Normand and Harold Lloyd. He mentored Charlie Chaplin and discovered Buster Keaton and Bob Hope." He was in the news in September 1921, accused of murder See, e.g., Great Falls tribune., September 13, 1921, Page 2 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045217/1921-09-13/ed-... "Murder Charge is Filed Against Arbuckle." Summary from Wikipedia: "Between November 1921 and April 1922, Arbuckle was the defendant in three widely publicized trials for the rape and manslaughter of actress Virginia Rappe. Rappe had fallen ill at a party hosted by Arbuckle at the St. Francis Hotel in San Francisco in September 1921; she died four days later. Arbuckle was accused by Rappe's acquaintance of raping and accidentally killing Rappe. After the first two trials, which resulted in hung juries, Arbuckle was acquitted in the third trial and received a formal written statement of apology from the jury. "

Presumably en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Washington_(BB-47) as seen recently in the Bain stream:

This is not the battleship BB 47, which was never completed and never entered service. More likely this is the troop transport USS GEORGE WASHINGTON (ID 3018), the former German passenger liner of that name seized by the US in April 1917. Commissioned by the US Navy in September 1917, she carried President Wilson to France in December 1918 for the Versailles conference. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_George_Washington

"John Wingate Weeks Historic Site's Mt. Prospect estate was built at the direction of John Wingate Weeks, leading conservationist, U.S. congressman, U.S. senator, and Secretary of War under Presidents Harding and Coolidge. The 446-acre Mt. Prospect estate was given to the state of New Hampshire in 1941 by John Weeks' children, Katherine Weeks Davidge and Sinclair Weeks. Set at the very top of Mt. Prospect in Lancaster, New Hampshire, the house and grounds provide a 360-degree panorama of mountain splendor, including the Presidential Range of the White Mountains, the Green Mountains of Vermont, the Kilkenny Range, the Percy Peaks, and the upper Connecticut River Valley. Visitors can climb the old stone fire tower for even better mountain views. The John Wingate Weeks House Museum is also open to the public and tours are offered during the operating season." www.nhstateparks.org/visit/state-parks/weeks-state-park

First, it's clearly not a blimp (a lighter than air craft whose gas bag derives its shape from gas pressure - not an internal frame), it's a rigid airship or dirigible. This one is correctly identified as the ZR-2, a US Navy craft. She had been built for Britain's Royal Navy as the R-38, but was purchased by the US while still under construction. She first flew on 23 June 1921 and fell apart and crashed on her fourth flight on 24 August 1921. Forty four men - both Americans and Britons - were killed in the crash. See: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R38-class_airship

"In 1970, a fast food chain based in St. Louis built at 1011 Veterans Highway a new Taco King restaurant but there were problems with the lease. A lawsuit ensued and the completed and fully-equipped building was placed on the market. Three businesses – Steak King International, Taco Villa and Joe’s Meat Market – opened and closed there before 1973, when South Seas Restaurant opened at that location. The new Chinese-American eatery found itself with a perfecty good, nearly-new eye-catching display sign towering over its parking. Unfortunately, it depicted a clearly Mexican man perching in a cactus. Whether inspired by thrift, Happy Hour, or weird sense of humor, someone “fixed” the former Taco King sign by giving its inhabitant a makeover, modifing his headgear, facial hair and eye shape to look more Asian. The end result didn’t achieve its goal but was memorable. South Seas endured for years before it and the sign were both demolished."

This is Major General Harry Lee, USMC (June 4 1872 - March 1 1933). Lee was appointed a Second Lieutenant in the US Marine Corps for the war with Spain August 2 1898. He served at the Havana Naval Station during the war and in various ships of the Navy and Marine Corps stations following it. Joining the 6th Regiment in 1917, Lee commanded the 6th Regiment at Chateau Thierry, St. Mihiel, and the Argonne Forest and marched with the Army to the Rhine. After the war he commanded the Marine Brigade in Santo Domingo, sent in 1921 to pacify the country and establish constitutional government. For 3 years he served as military governor of the country. Later General Lee commanded Marine Barracks, Parris Island, and while in command of the Marine base at Quantico, Va., died March 1 1933. For his World War I service, Major General Lee was awarded the Army and Navy Distinguished Service Medals, the French Legion of Honor, and other decorations. Bio from: www.navalcovermuseum.org/wiki/HARRY_LEE_APA_10

"Diana Olivia Winifred Maud Cooper, Viscountess Norwich (née Lady Diana Manners; 29 August 1892 – 16 June 1986) was a famously glamorous social figure in London and Paris. As a young woman, she moved in a celebrated group of intellectuals known as the Coterie, most of whom were killed in the First World War. She married one of the few survivors, Duff Cooper, later British Ambassador to France. After his death, she wrote three volumes of memoirs which reveal much about early 20th-century upper-class life." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lady_Diana_Cooper

She was an actress, known for movie The House of a Thousand Candles (1915). She died in November 1977 in Bar Harbor, Maine, USA. www.imdb.com/name/nm0733479/ which says she was active on Broadway 1914-28 and lists some shows in www.imdb.com/name/nm0733479/otherworks?ref_=nm_pdt_wrk_sm This seems to match the Mary Robson at www.ibdb.com/broadway-cast-staff/mary-robson-58101 I haven't been able to convince myself which Mary (or May) Robson this Bain photo might be of. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045433/1916-02-06/ed-... has a photo of a Mary Robson in the upper right, captioned to indicate she was to be in "The Masked Model." Elsewhere on the page (column 1), she is mentioned as the dark-eyed beauty of "The Honeymoon Express." I can't be sure the photo is of the same woman that we see here. Neither play is mentioned in en.wikipedia.org/wiki/May_Robson or www.ibdb.com/broadway-cast-staff/mary-robson-58101 I tried following these two plays up to see if I could find pictures, but without luck. The Masked Model opened in Atlantic City, with a Mary Robson in it. See timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1916/02/01/10018793... but apparently flopped in previews and either never opened or closed quickly on Broadway. See books.google.com/books?id=qPbeCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA151&l... The Honeymoon Express was on Broadway in 1913, but there was no Mary Robson in the opening night cast. See www.ibdb.com/broadway-production/the-honeymoon-express-7595 That's as much digging I can do for now.

www.ncpedia.org/biography/patterson-lucy Lucy Bramlette Patterson Patterson, 22 Aug. 1865–20 June 1942 "organizational leader, literary figure, and Republican national committeewoman, was born at Castle Rock, her mother's family home in Tazewell, Tenn., the daughter of Colonel William Houston and Cornelia Humes Graham Patterson. Her paternal grandfather, Major General Robert Patterson who had fought in the War of 1812, the Mexican War, and the Civil War on the Union side, lived in Philadelphia. She was graduated in 1882 from Salem Academy, where her mother had also gone to school; there she met her future husband, a promising young lawyer, J. Lindsay Patterson, who became a distinguished attorney, a trustee of The University of North Carolina (like his father and grandfather before him), and prominent throughout the state. They were married on 6 Sept. 1888."

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ivanoe_Bonomi "Ivanoe Bonomi [iˈvaːnoe boˈnɔːmi] (18 October 1873 – 20 April 1951) was an Italian statesman before and after World War II and ruled Italy as the 25th Prime Minister of Italy." "Bonomi served as Minister of Public Works from 1916 until 1917, and as Minister of War from 1920 until 1921 - helping to negotiate a treaty with Yugoslavia (the Treaty of Rapallo). Later in 1921 he became Treasury Minister. A few months later, he became Prime Minister of Italy for the first time, in a coalition government—the first socialist to hold the post. Early in 1922, his government collapsed, and he was replaced as Prime Minister by Luigi Facta, amidst the Fascist insurgency led by Benito Mussolini. In October 1922, Mussolini gained power through the March on Rome, and Bonomi withdrew from politics."

cinematreasures.org/theaters/23 Boston Opera House 539 Washington Street, Boston, MA 02111 "The B.F. Keith Memorial Theatre was a vaudeville house in Boston’s theater district. It opened on October 29, 1928 with the film “Oh Kay” starring Colleen Moore. This beautiful house later became part of the RKO theater chain and the RKO Keith’s switched to a movies only format. Its name was later changed to the Savoy Theatre and was purchased by Sack Theatres. In 1978, the Savoy Theatre was sold by Sack to the Opera Company of Boston, and the theater became known as the Opera House, for which it was used until 1990. The theater was renovated, restored, and reopened in July 2004 by Clear Channel Entertainment, and is now a site for touring Broadway shows and other live entertainment, known as the Boston Opera House." Looks like Princess Fatima also makes an appearance in the San Diego Air & Space Museum (SDASM) collection in the Flickr Commons. The photo below is part of their Theodore "Ted" Hall Special Collection album. Note impostor Stanley Clifford Weyman seemingly dressed as US Navy officer (it is actually a United States Junior Naval Reserves uniform) on the left side of the frame. He entered Princess Fatima's circle by (falsely) claiming he was a US State Department Naval Liaison Officer - despite the fact that there was no such actual posting or position (Wikipedia link). Remarkably, another impostor had joined Princess Fatima's entourage, Zerdecheno Mohamid Saide Kakelo, alias "The Prince of Kurdistan." He is also captured in the photo below. Click on the photo to read more, and for additional citations.: www.flickr.com/photos/sdasmarchives/10317217134/

A graduate of École Centrale Paris, he made his name building various bridges for the French railway network, most famously the Garabit viaduct. He is best known for the world-famous Eiffel Tower, built for the 1889 Universal Exposition in Paris, and his contribution to building the Statue of Liberty in New York. Later, the Bavetta brothers formed their own professional band named, “V[ito]. Bavetta’s Concert Band”. The bands played regularly at Dreamland at Coney Island, Luna Park in Brooklyn, and the Hotel Riccadonna at Brighton Beach."

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suzanne_Lenglen "Suzanne Rachel Flore Lenglen (French pronunciation: ​[sy.zan lɑ̃.glɛn]; 24 May 1899 – 4 July 1938) was a French tennis player who won 31 Championship titles between 1914 and 1926. She dominated women's tennis from 1914 until 1926 when she turned professional. A flamboyant, trendsetting athlete, she was the first female tennis celebrity and one of the first international female sport stars, named La Divine (the Goddess) by the French press. Lenglen's 241 titles, 181 match winning streak and 341-7 (98%) match record are hard to imagine happening in today's tennis atmosphere."

Streetview 2018 From registration for Downtown Historic District [ www.historycolorado.org/sites/default/files/media/documen... ] "105 E. Main St., 5FN.2284, Dr. Morgan Office, ca. 1927 (Photograph 37) This plain, one-story brown brick building with flat roof has some characteristics of the Mediterranean Revival style. The front façade (south side) has a central entrance with brick arch and inset wood door with three stepped lights. Flanking the entrance are flat arch plate-glass windows with brick sills. There is a center flat parapet above the entrance and projecting piers at each end of the wall. Between the piers and the parapet are slanting bands of metal tile. At the top and bottom of the wall are contrasting courses of red brick. Alterations. A 1981 survey photo shows the same door but the window openings have glass block; neither are believed to be original. The date the original windows and door were removed is unknown. Historic Background. A previous building on this site was removed by 1926, when Sanborn maps show the parcel to be vacant. The current building is shown on a 1949 map. In 1955, Dr. A.W. Morgan, an osteopath and surgeon, had his office here and in 1957, Bramer & Tull Optometrists were located here. In 1964, the Florence Chamber of Commerce had offices here, and Anthony Scutti was the secretary and manager for the organization. The 1981 survey found that the building was used as an annex of the First National Bank of Florence. Rocky Mountain Bank & Trust began utilizing the building in the early 2000s. "

American Exporter, August 1921 books.google.com/books?id=P1hLAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA84-IA13&a... shows him as part of a delegation of Japanese lawmakers to the U. S. The caption says that he was Speaker of the Japanese House of Parliament.

See also timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1921/06/24/10980960... His japanese wikipedia entry: ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E4%B8%AD%E8%A5%BF%E5%85%AD%E4%B8%8... Translation by google: "Nakanishi Rokuzaburo ... (March 13, 1866 - February 3, 1930) was a member of the House of Representatives of Japan → constitutional m political party → independent, lawyer" According to books.google.com/books?id=4UkhAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA594&lp..., he was a judge and a member of the Lower House.
Harvard Library Notes, November 1921 books.google.com/books?id=EoEoAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA122&l... has him as Envoy of the Special Chinese Mission.

The New-York tribune., June 23, 1921, Page 3, col. 6 reported that "Another group of travelers, described as a mission of friendship and made up entirely of Chinamen, arrived on the (liner) Paris headed by Chu Chi Chen, China's Minister of the Interior." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1921-06-23/ed-... According to The evening world., June 24, 1921, Baseball Final, Image 6, col. 4, "CHINESE SEEK IDEAS HERE", he was a former Premier of China. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1921-06-24/ed-... There was a Premier called Xu Shichang (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xu_Shichang), but he seems significantly older (and was President of China at that time).

On the other hand, there is a certain similarity with Chang Ch'ih-t'an (born 1883). According to prabook.com/web/chih-t_an.chang/1344473, Chang Ch'ih-t'an was Acting Minister of the Interior until May 1921.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_Paris_(1916) "The SS Paris was a French ocean liner built in Saint-Nazaire, France for the Compagnie Générale Transatlantique. The French Line's Paris was built by Chantiers de l'Atlantique of St. Nazaire. Although Paris was laid down in 1913, her launching was delayed until 1916, and she was not completed until 1921, due to World War I. When Paris was finally completed, she was the largest liner under the French flag, at 34,569 tons."

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/25695066@N00] Hello Jonathan. I think you have identified the Aeromarine "Waldorf" cleanly but I was not able to link the name 'Waldorf" of this flying boat to the Model 85. There seems to be only an incomplete list of names of the ca. 15 Model 85 flying boats, about 7 names are identified but not the "Waldorf".

Thank you for the comment, Kees. Looking into this deeper, I came across some information that should secure Waldorf's identity as an Aeromarine Model 85 flying boat. At The Aeromarine Website, Waldorf is identified as an "Aeromarine Model 85/80" among a list of aircraft operated by the airline. Both types of aircraft were modified surplus HS-2L flying boats, but the Model 80 could be distinguished from Model 85 by the Model 80's addition of an enclosed passenger cabin (which Waldorf lacks). Further, just a bit of circumstantial evidence, all of the Aeromarine Airways' aircraft named after famous hotels and captured in photos - Ambassador, McAlpin, Vanderbilt, and Biltmore - were Model 85s, like Waldorf. However, the best evidence as to Waldorf's type is a two-page Aeromarine advertisement in Aviation and Aircraft Journal, February 7, 1921, Vol. X, No. 6, on pages 173-174. The ad illustrates the company's line of surplus HS-2L (and derived) aircraft, including the Model 85 as "Aeromarine-Navy HS-2-L, Six Seat. Open Cockpit Flying Boat, Model No. 85," and "Aeromarine-Navy HS-2-L, Enclosed Cabin De Luxe Flying Limousine, Model No. 80." As an aside, this ad is in the middle of a pretty interesting article about the company, spanning pages 171-176. As best I can tell, from The Aeromarine Website, contemporary direct sources - like the company's advertisements, the configuration of the aircraft, etc., the best available evidence points to Waldorf being a Model 85 flying boat.

Thanks  [https://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05], we do have the wrong address on here. In trying to confirm it, I went through lots of newspaper articles, ads, and maps. After consulting some maps, I believe that road in the foreground is McCormick St., which now dead ends at a parking garage, but before the reconstruction crossed over to Lankershim. That would make sense with the photo you linked to if it was taken at Lankershim and Magnolia, it would then be looking toward the Woolworth's and McCormack St. 

If anyone confirm this or correct me, please do.

Woolworth's address was 5248 Lankershim, on the corner of McCormick. It wasn't at Magnolia, which is the 5200 block of Lankershim. The numbers even at the south end of Lankershim  don't go as low as 3200.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Cordelle_Bone "Scott Cardelle Bone (February 15, 1860 – January 26, 1936) was the fourth Territorial Governor of Alaska, serving from 1921–1925. A Republican, he was appointed by President Warren G. Harding. He is perhaps best known for making the decision to use dog sleds to transport diphtheria antitoxin 674 miles rather than use a plane in the now-famous 1925 Serum Run, (also known as the "Great Race of Mercy") from which the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race stems."

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dorothy_Gish "Dorothy Elizabeth Gish (March 11, 1898 – June 4, 1968) was an American actress of the screen and stage, as well as a director and writer. Dorothy and her older sister Lillian Gish were major movie stars of the silent era. Dorothy also had great success on the stage, and was inducted into the American Theatre Hall of Fame. Dorothy Gish was noted as a fine comedian, and many of her films were comedies."

Here's more on the Remy Glider (Océano-glisseur Remy), along with additional photos. You'll see the finished prototype wasn't quite as sleek as the model captured in the photo above. The site is in French, but can be translated. Le Bateau du Havre en cartes postales - Histoire étonnante de l’Océanoglisseur le "Malgrétout", de l’ingénieur Remy (The Ships of Le Havre in Postcards - "Amazing story of the Oceanic Glider the "Malgrétout", the engineer Remy") Unfortunately, it would seem financial hardships would bring the project to an end. Here is a rough translation of the described conclusion of the Remy Glider's story:
"We remember the Océano slider that came to moor in Trouville, and its setbacks. Two men of the crew had fled off on the craft. They were overtaken and the aircraft returned to Le Havre where creditors sued the inventor. Later, he was moored at the wharf at Caudebec-en-Caux, where for six months he had been in receivership. On the order of the court, he has just been put on sale and awarded 7,000 francs to a mechanic from Le Havre. "
Here are additional stories about the effort, published in 1928 by Popular Science: "Plans to Cross Ocean in 60 Hours - Frenchman's Unsinkable Ocean-Glider Will Dash from France at Seventy Knots an Hour in a Few Weeks, Declared Inventor," by Edwin Ketchum, Popular Science, April 1928, Page 49.
Paris to New York in sixty hours! That is the mark set for himself by Adrien Remy, French inventor of a new type of speed boat, whose craft is shortly to undertake the trans-Atlantic passage. Already at a marine works on Saint-Ouen, near Paris, finishing touches are being applied to the full-size vessel that grew out of Remy's first plans. Early this April, if his project is carried through according to schedule, the craft will snort into New York harbor at a speed of seventy knots an hour!
"Sixty-Hour Trans-Atlantic Speed Boat Ready to Go," Popular Science, August 1928, Page 69.
Not long ago the little French town of Javel, on the rive Seine, looked and marveled at the strangest water craft it had ever seen. It had just been trundled on heavy trucks from the marine works at Saint-Ouens, and assembled on blocks for launching. among the curious crowd stood its inventor, Adrien Remy, watching his dream come true. It was an "ocean-glider," he said, with a tanklike engine room and cabin swung on a steel framework between two cigar-shaped pontoons that would carry it safely through the fiercest Atlantic storms he might encounter...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Strauss "Richard Georg Strauss (German pronunciation: [ˈʁɪçaʁt ˈʃtʁaʊs]; 11 June 1864 – 8 September 1949) was a leading German composer of the late Romantic and early modern eras. He is known for his operas, which include Der Rosenkavalier, Elektra, Die Frau ohne Schatten and Salome; his Lieder, especially his Four Last Songs; his tone poems, including Don Juan, Death and Transfiguration, Till Eulenspiegel's Merry Pranks, Also sprach Zarathustra, Ein Heldenleben, Symphonia Domestica, and An Alpine Symphony; and other instrumental works such as Metamorphosen and his Oboe Concerto. Strauss was also a prominent conductor in Western Europe and the Americas, enjoying quasi-celebrity status as his compositions became standards of orchestral and operatic repertoire."
